FY 22-23.mission: The RNA Epitranscriptomics and Proteomics Resources (REPR) was created by consolidating the RNA analysis and proteomics capabilities existing at the University at Albany. This specialized resource offers an extensive range of state-of-the-art mass spectrometry instrumentation and know-how. The mission is to capitalize on the extensive expertise in the analysis of RNA, RNA modifications, and proteins involved in RNA metabolism/regulation to benefit both internal and external investigators interested in these types of topics.
FY 22-23.vision: ​​The resource supports also projects involving the analysis of a wide range of biomolecules, metabolites, and small synthetic molecules. In addition to providing full-service analysis, REPR welcomes the opportunity to enter full-fledged partnerships that may involve extensive consulting on experimental design, sample preparation and data interpretation, as well as whole project development and grant writing contributions. Please, contact us to inquire on how we can best help you.

FY 22-23.mission: The mission of the New York State Mesonet (NYSM) is to serve the state of New York by providing the best meteorological data, the best products, and the best services possible with the goal of saving lives and property while building a smart weather economy. At its core, the NYSM is a highly dedicated, cross-disciplinary team aspiring to set the worldwide standard of excellence for data quality. With its unique focus on research to operations, preventive maintenance, and state-of-the-art quality control efforts, the NYSM utilizes these high quality weather data to create end products designed to improve forecast accuracy, reduce uncertainty, and mitigate harm.
FY 22-23.vision: ​​The vision of the New York State Mesonet is to become a national center, collaborating with government, academic, and commercial partners, to educate and solve real-world problems in agriculture, emergency management, energy, public health, and transportation, improving the well being and livelihood for all.
FY 22-23.annualBudget:
Approximately $1M.  Actual need is ~ $2.5M.
Money received is a mix of federal money from the National Mesonet Program (via private contractor), direct funds from research grants, and university support.

FY 22-23.mission: To provide ion beam irradiation and implantation education, training, and services to researchers from UAlbany, other academic insitutions, federal research agencies, and private industry to probe structure of materials, affect modification of structure by and impact of ion irradiation on their physical, chemical, and electronic properties.
FY 22-23.vision: ​​The Ion Beam Laboratory (IBL) strives to remain one of the leading laboratory of its kind in the nation and offer a wide variety of irradiation, measurement, and analysis facilities and services to researchers. The IBL assists its users and partners in advancing the science and technology of biological, chemical, solid state, and electronic materials leading to the growth of new businesses in New York state and the country.
FY 22-23.goal1: ​​To design and install a new vacuum and control system on the Dynamitron accelerator. This will allow the facility to be prepared to meet the needs of the next generation of micro chip research, in addition to the ever more demanding precision required by other research activities.​
FY 22-23.goal2: ​​Increase the use of the facility by outside clients which will increase revenues and IBL participation in a wider range of research efforts. Increase the amount of analysis work done by IBL staff on behalf of outside clients which would also increase revenue. Prepare for the increased usage of the IBL due to the passing of the Chips Act.
FY 22-23.goal3: ​​Design and build a low energy Ion implantation accelerator to service the need of the NASA Genesis project.
FY 22-23.goal4: ​​The successful acquisition of the standard sample.
FY 22-23.actions1: ​​The addition of a second permanent engineer to assist in the redesign and installation efforts. The successful award of a $ 500,00.00 earmark grant to cover the costs.
FY 22-23.actions2: ​​Redesigning the website making it easier for clients to use to access IBL services. Direct marketing efforts performed by IBL staff to increase business.
FY 22-23.actions3: ​​The addition of a second permanent engineer to assist in the design and construction efforts. The successful award of a $ 500,00.00 earmark grant to cover the costs.
FY 22-23.actions4: ​​The successful acquisition of the standard sample.
FY 22-23.metrics1: The success of the project will be measure by a decrease in EM noise in measured data, and a marked increase in vacuum purity.
FY 22-23.metrics2: An increase in revenue for the IBL in these areas.
FY 22-23.metrics3: ​​The successful construction of a functioning accelerator.
FY 22-23.timeframe1: It will take one year after receiving the resources to the completion of the project, it will be possible to assess the success at that time.
FY 22-23.timeframe4: Withing six months of obtaining the sample.

FY 22-23.mission: Transforming public services through innovations in management, policy, and technology.
FY 22-23.vision: ​ ​The Center for Technology in Government (CTG UAlbany) was established in 1993 to pursue new ways to use technology to address practical problems of information management and service delivery in government. It soon developed into an internationally-recognized research center within the University at Albany whose mission is to foster public sector innovation, enhance capability, generate public value, and support good governance. To achieve this mission, CTG UAlbany pursues the following strategic actions • To engage in innovative academic and applied research on complex societal challenges • To become global leaders in digital government research and public sector digital transformation • To develop and teach innovative courses that emphasize real-life applications of technology, management, policy, and data in the public sector • To enable students to learn about societal challenges and apply technologies and policies in the context of specific projects • To engage diverse professional communities in the transformation of public services CTG UAlbany's competitive advantage • Unique combination of disciplines (public administration and public management, computer science, information systems, data science, business, international relations) • Highly skilled academic and professional staff, who help bridge the gap between academia and practice by addressing public problems that are academically significant and practically relevant • Network orchestrator, locally (government organizations, diverse stakeholders) and internationally (leader of multiple research networks) • Co-creation approach in projects with government organizations that enable their engagement in creative problem-solving processes and the implementation of innovative and customized digital transformation solutions to complex problems • “Center for Technology in Government” as a worldwide recognized “brand” developed and consolidated during the last 30 years • Key location, close to decision-makers and international hubs
FY 22-23.annualBudget: CTG’s revenue stream consists of research grants and awards, corporate sponsored projects, and research agreements supported through the Research Foundation, as well as various University at Albany state and municipal MOUs and contract projects. This year, CTG will realize $429,245 in IFR revenue from seven RF projects and $265,182 from four state-side MOUs and contracts. Due to an overpayment on our Water Quality project by the sponsor, $115,255 of these funds were returned to the DEC. In addition, $68,294 in At-Risk Funding was returned by the budget office to our IFR account. Finally, total state overhead paid on these awards was $64,927. Taking all these factors into account, our net revenue for CTG FY 2021-2022 was $582,539. The remaining revenue helped to support annual operating expenses of $435,025. The expense categories included phones, technical equipment and software, postage, graduate students, temp service and term positions, supplies, service contracts, online and in-person training and conferences, non-project supported travel, state project-related expenses, and any other non-PSR expense needed to operate CTG. This figure also includes fringe for all non-student categories. CTG does not receive an annual OTPS allocation from the Division of Research, instead it revenue generates on its own to support CTG’s OTPS budget. CTG also received an allocation from Rock College to the PSR account in the amount of $18,000. This was used to cover temp salary expenses on our 900309 IFR account. CTG’s PSR state allocation of $680,857supported 6.34 FTEs. This was reduced by $176,318 from last year’s state allocation of $857,175 and 8 FTEs in order to help support the state-side budget deficit. Due to these reductions in state supported PSR, this year CTG needed to use IFR funds to support 2 research-related positions in order to continue the work needed on various research awards, including a researcher in digital government and a program associate. CTG continues to be very strategic with our business development goals and is committed to seeking out new funding opportunities and partnerships. This year, CTG was awarded a total of $923,419 through new State and RF awards. New State MOUs and contract awards included The NYS Board of Elections Futures (Phase II) award for $349,945 and the NYS Board of Elections Local Government Risk Remediation (Part 2) award for $39,000. Total new state awards equaled $388,945. New awards through the Research Foundation included a 3-year Message Design Dashboard: Development of a Standardized Messaging Tool through FEMA at $327,012 for year 1. Also, the City of Schenectady awarded the project, Enabling the State-Wide Rollout of the Share Regional Information Resource in the amount of $189,462. The NYS Association of Counties awarded CTG $16,000 to develop a Cyber Primer for local IT leaders. In addition, we received a gift in kind from NVIDIA to provide equipment and training for the TAF project already underway and is valued at approximately $2,000. Total New RF awards equaled $923,419. In addition, CTG has two proposals pending including the NSF Large-scale CoPe: Bridging Data to Action - Using Data and AI to Develop Equitable Outcomes While Augmenting Resilience to Climate Hazards in Coastal Communities for $864,923. Also submitted was a proposal to NSF for the Civic Innovation Challenge 2022 Planning Grant in coordination with the City of Schenectady for $50,000. Total potential new revenue awarded in the coming fiscal year totals $914,923. Residual funds not utilized in the next fiscal year will be used in the coming years to help continue support for the two temporary research IFR funded positions mentioned above, including our Researcher in Digital Government, as well as our Program Associate.

FY 23-24.mission: ​​Transforming public services through innovations in management, policy, and technology.
FY 23-24.vision: ​ ​The Center for Technology in Government (CTG UAlbany) was established in 1993 to pursue new ways to use technology to address practical problems of information management and service delivery in government. It soon developed into an internationally-recognized research center within the University at Albany whose mission is to foster public sector innovation, enhance capability, generate public value, and support good governance. To achieve this mission, CTG UAlbany pursues the following strategic actions • To engage in innovative academic and applied research on complex societal challenges • To become global leaders in digital government research and public sector digital transformation • To develop and teach innovative courses that emphasize real-life applications of technology, management, policy, and data in the public sector • To enable students to learn about societal challenges and apply technologies and policies in the context of specific projects • To engage diverse professional communities in the transformation of public services CTG UAlbany's competitive advantage • Unique combination of disciplines (public administration and public management, computer science, information systems, data science, business, international relations) • Highly skilled academic and professional staff, who help bridge the gap between academia and practice by addressing public problems that are academically significant and practically relevant • Network orchestrator, locally (government organizations, diverse stakeholders) and internationally (leader of multiple research networks) • Co-creation approach in projects with government organizations that enable their engagement in creative problem-solving processes and the implementation of innovative and customized digital transformation solutions to complex problems • “Center for Technology in Government” as a worldwide recognized “brand” developed and consolidated during the last 30 years • Key location, close to decision-makers and international hubs
FY 23-24.annualBudget: ​​CTG’s revenue stream consists of research grants and awards, corporate sponsored projects, and research agreements supported through the Research Foundation, as well as various University at Albany state and municipal MOUs and contract projects. This year, CTG will realize $429,245 in IFR revenue from seven RF projects and $265,182 from four state-side MOUs and contracts. Due to an overpayment on our Water Quality project by the sponsor, $115,255 of these funds were returned to the DEC. In addition, $68,294 in At-Risk Funding was returned by the budget office to our IFR account. Finally, total state overhead paid on these awards was $64,927. Taking all these factors into account, our net revenue for CTG FY 2021-2022 was $582,539. The remaining revenue helped to support annual operating expenses of $435,025. The expense categories included phones, technical equipment and software, postage, graduate students, temp service and term positions, supplies, service contracts, online and in-person training and conferences, non-project supported travel, state project-related expenses, and any other non-PSR expense needed to operate CTG. This figure also includes fringe for all non-student categories. CTG does not receive an annual OTPS allocation from the Division of Research, instead it revenue generates on its own to support CTG’s OTPS budget. CTG also received an allocation from Rock College to the PSR account in the amount of $18,000. This was used to cover temp salary expenses on our 900309 IFR account. CTG’s PSR state allocation of $680,857supported 6.34 FTEs. This was reduced by $176,318 from last year’s state allocation of $857,175 and 8 FTEs in order to help support the state-side budget deficit. Due to these reductions in state supported PSR, this year CTG needed to use IFR funds to support 2 research-related positions in order to continue the work needed on various research awards, including a researcher in digital government and a program associate. CTG continues to be very strategic with our business development goals and is committed to seeking out new funding opportunities and partnerships. This year, CTG was awarded a total of $923,419 through new State and RF awards. New State MOUs and contract awards included The NYS Board of Elections Futures (Phase II) award for $349,945 and the NYS Board of Elections Local Government Risk Remediation (Part 2) award for $39,000. Total new state awards equaled $388,945. New awards through the Research Foundation included a 3-year Message Design Dashboard Development of a Standardized Messaging Tool through FEMA at $327,012 for year 1. Also, the City of Schenectady awarded the project, Enabling the State-Wide Rollout of the Share Regional Information Resource in the amount of $189,462. The NYS Association of Counties awarded CTG $16,000 to develop a Cyber Primer for local IT leaders. In addition, we received a gift in kind from NVIDIA to provide equipment and training for the TAF project already underway and is valued at approximately $2,000. Total New RF awards equaled $923,419. In addition, CTG has two proposals pending including the NSF Large-scale CoPe Bridging Data to Action - Using Data and AI to Develop Equitable Outcomes While Augmenting Resilience to Climate Hazards in Coastal Communities for $864,923. Also submitted was a proposal to NSF for the Civic Innovation Challenge 2022 Planning Grant in coordination with the City of Schenectady for $50,000. Total potential new revenue awarded in the coming fiscal year totals $914,923. Residual funds not utilized in the next fiscal year will be used in the coming years to help continue support for the two temporary research IFR funded positions mentioned above, including our Researcher in Digital Government, as well as our Program Associate.

FY 22-23.mission: CSDA's mission is to facilitate and organize population research and education of the highest caliber. It seeks to accomplish this mission by creating a stimulating and cohesive intellectual environment conducive to the development of multidisciplinary population scholarship, particularly on the Center's signature themes of spatial inequalities and vulnerable populations. Key areas of research include: health and health disparities, immigration, risks to youth and adolescents, spatial inequalities and migration, American families, and social resources and vulnerabilities of the elderly.
FY 22-23.vision: ​​Our vision is to increase our funding portfolio, forge linkages with other units on campus that don't know about CSDA, attract students from underrepresented minority groups to engage in population-based research, and conduct strategic planning to solidify our larger vision moving forward.
FY 22-23.annualBudget: At this point, we have no other sources of budget for our half-time employee, Jin-Wook Lee, who we share with the Lewis Mumford Center (AVAIL). We have three grants pending that will pay for a small portion of Jin's services. Two have gotten fundable scores and are pending final review, which should come in June/July 2022. The other was just put under review at NIEHS in April.

FY 22-23.goal1: ​​Our first priority is to increase our funding portfolio, with an emphasis on applying for grants in the Population Dynamics Branch (PDB) of NICHD.  Expanding funding in the latter agency will increase our ability to be successful in being funding by a future center grant from NICHD.
FY 22-23.goal2: ​​Our second main goal is to continue to forge linkages with other units on campus that either do not know about CSDA or have started to know about CSDA. We are particularly interested in continuing to develop capacity for our research associates to engage in research that links climate change and disasters to the demographics that they are currently studying and that are CSDA’s themes – health, migration, and spatial inequalities. None of our CSDA associates are currently from the College of Emergency Preparedness, Homeland Security, and Cybersecurity (CEHC) or from the Department of Atmospheric and Environmental Sciences. However, the research that is conducted in both units is focused on disasters and climate change, which has implications for all of the main foci of CSDA. We would also like to forge linkages with the Department of Computer Science and College of Engineering.
FY 22-23.goal3: ​​Our third priority is to explore ways to attract students, particularly underrepresented minorities, to engage in population-based research, enhance student experiences of those already engaged in population-based research, and ultimately, through the former endeavors, grow a workforce to assist CSDA associates.
FY 22-23.actions1:
​​
To achieve this goal, we will 1) have a colloquium series this year to showcase successful NICHD grantees from other universities and their research; 2)  organize meetings around each of our core themes -- 1) population health; 2) immigration and internal migration; and 3) spatial inequalities -- with our faculty associates working in those areas to identify opportunities for future collaboration as it fits with the Population Dynamics Branch of PDB.
FY 22-23.actions2: ​​1) Host meetings to facilitate connections between our CSDA associates and researchers on campus outside of CSDA that work on climate change and disasters and/or social networks/computing. 2) Invite key stakeholders like Chris Thorncroft and Eric Stern to be on our Advisory Board. 3) Continue to explore funding mechanisms to bring collaborations across these units. At a meeting I recently attended of the Association of Population Centers, we were informed that a working group at NICHD is discussing potential funding options linking climate change and health.
FY 22-23.actions3: ​​To achieve this goal, we will 1) identify our associates who are working on research with undergraduates; 2) make CSDA activities more visible to undergraduates at UAlbany by encouraging their participation in our colloquium series and by holding virtual events surrounding Census 2020; 3) network with other departments who do not know about CSDA but whose students could be of great value to CSDA associates (e.g., data science, statistics, and information science); and 4) form a small group of CSDA associates that will collaborate to write a proposal for the National Science Foundation Research Experience for Undergraduates due in August 2021.
FY 22-23.metrics1: We will measure our success by gauging the increase in applications for funding to NICHD and other funding agencies.
FY 22-23.metrics2: 1) Number of meetings2) Number of attendees at meetings3) Number of collaborative publications4) Number of collaborative grants5) Number of new CSDA associates from ASRC/CEHC and other departments
FY 22-23.metrics3: ​​Our success will be based upon our ability to attract undergraduate students to participate in our events; to involve more undergraduate and graduate students of color in the research of CSDA associates; and to apply for funding via the NSF REU mechanism.

FY 23-24.mission: ​​CSDA's mission is to facilitate and organize population research and education of the highest caliber. It seeks to accomplish this mission by creating a stimulating and cohesive intellectual environment conducive to the development of multidisciplinary population scholarship, particularly on the Center's signature themes of spatial inequalities and vulnerable populations.  Key areas of research include health and health disparities, immigration, risks to youth and adolescents, spatial inequalities and migration, American families, and social resources and vulnerabilities of the elderly.
FY 23-24.vision: ​​Our vision is to increase our funding portfolio, forge linkages with other units on campus that don't know about CSDA, attract students from underrepresented minority groups to engage in population-based research, and conduct strategic planning to solidify our larger vision moving forward.
FY 23-24.annualBudget: ​​At this point, we have no other sources of budget for our half-time employee, Jin-Wook Lee, who we share with the Lewis Mumford Center (AVAIL). We are working on finding other sources of funding for Mr. Lee.

FY 22-23.unit: Center for Elimination of Minority Health Disparities
FY 22-23.mission: The mission of the Center for the Elimination of Minority Health Disparities (CEMHD) is to contribute to the elimination of minority health disparities in the smaller cities and towns of New York State. CEMHD’s activities focus on three major interrelated areas, in the service of contributing to the elimination of minority health disparities: community engagement, fostering health disparities research, and supporting the development of new health disparities scholars.
FY 22-23.vision: ​​The Center for the Elimination of Minority Health Disparities (CEMHD), is a collaborative effort focusing on minority health disparities in the smaller cities and towns of New York. Home to a 2016 NIMHD S21 Health Disparities Endowment Grant, a 2009 NIMHD P20 Exploratory Center of Excellence, and a 2004 NIMHD R24 EXPORT Center, CEMHD works toward eliminating health disparities by developing capacity in faculty at the University at Albany and partnering with community groups to identify their health concerns and the sources of disparities, and then plans, implements and tests strategies to alleviate them. CEMHD is a partnership among community groups, hospitals, state and county health departments, the State of New York and the University at Albany. CEMHD's focus on minorities and under-served populations in the smaller cities and towns of Upstate New York is premised upon the notion that health disparities found in these areas differ from those in the larger cities, and that the appropriate solutions will also differ. Since most of the research on minority health disparities, and the programs that have resulted from it, has focused on populations in large cities, relatively little is known about the distinct causes of poorer health among minorities in smaller cities. Therefore, another reason for our geographical emphasis is to fill in a gap in the research and to initiate and test the appropriate solutions.

FY 22-23.topAchievements1:
​
​Doctoral training

a. Two new Health Disparities Training Fellows (HDTFs) were admitted for Fall 2021, chosen from among 46 applications, one to the Dept. of Latin American and Caribbean Studies and the other to the School of Public Health’s Dept. of Biomedical Sciences. Two students who joined the program in Fall 2017 successfully defended their dissertations (December/January), with degree conferral anticipated in spring/summer 2022. An additional defense is scheduled for August 2022. Three Fellows were admitted with support from the Hearst Foundations, one to the Dept. of Sociology, and two to Biology.
b. All of the S21-supported HDTFs (n=9) who began in fall of 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, and 2021 have been retained through the current academic year. In addition, two fellows supported by Hearst Foundations that entered in 2020 have been retained, as have the three Hearst supported Fellows who entered in fall 2021.
FY 22-23.topAchievements2:
​
​Hiring diverse faculty

a. A search is currently underway for a preeminent, nationally recognized scholar to anchor and lead the University’s efforts in health disparities research, training and outreach, with support from the Endowment for Community-Based Health Disparities Research and Training (S21 MD01069202), the SUNY Empire Innovation Professor (EIP) Program, and the University at Albany. An appointment is expected on or before June 30, 2022.
FY 22-23.topAchievements3:
​
​Training faculty researchers, community members and leaders, HDTFs and their mentors in health disparities research by hosting events that expose participants to the latest developments in the field, and bring people together to share ideas, and gain expertise and support.
In April 2022, CEMHD hosted the fourth President’s forum entitled “Moving to Action in the Achievement of Health Equity” virtually (click here: www.albany.edu/healthdisparitiesforum). The keynote speech by Dr. Camara Phyllis Jones, a national expert on equity and health issues, “Achieving Health Equity: Naming Racism and Moving to Action” focused on the social and behavioral factors influencing racial differences on health outcomes and quality of life for African Americans. There were 231 registrations and 131 attendees, including Community partners, government officials, researchers, faculty, professional staff, postdoctoral associates, and students. This year’s Forum included, in addition to the keynote speaker and reaction panel, 3 concurrent panels, organized around the topics of Environmental Health Disparities, Maternal Health Disparities, and Health Communication, Digital Divide, and Messaging. Each panel featured 3 faculty researchers, as well as a community based practitioner.
FY 22-23.topAchievements4:
​
​Contributing to elevating the visibility of minority health disparities and health equity achievement as a central theme and signature strength of the University, such that training and research in this area will be ongoing for the foreseeable future, with S21 supported activities playing a central role.

The NIMHD S21 Endowment Program – particularly through its President’s Forum and Speakers Series – continues to raise the visibility of the University at Albany as a hub for health disparities research, training, and community outreach throughout Albany County, the greater Capital Region, the State of New York, and the northeastern United States. The endowment award and its invigoration of CEMHD drew the attention of the Governor of New York State in the spring of 2020, resulting in a request by the Governor to the University president to prepare a report on the differential impact of COVID-19 on communities of color.

The University at Albany’s academic and research community is now very aware of the NIMHD S21 Endowment award, especially the Health Disparities Research Training program. Academic departments across the University know about the funding opportunity for applicants to their doctoral programs, and applications to the program are steadily increasing.

FY 23-24.unit: Center for Elimination of Minority Health Disparities
FY 23-24.mission: ​​The mission of the Center for the Elimination of Minority Health Disparities (CEMHD) is to contribute to the elimination of minority health disparities in the smaller cities and towns of New York State. CEMHD’s activities focus on three major interrelated areas, in the service of contributing to the elimination of minority health disparities: community engagement, fostering health disparities research, and supporting the development of new health disparities scholars.
FY 23-24.vision: ​​The Center for the Elimination of Minority Health Disparities (CEMHD), is a collaborative effort focusing on minority health disparities in the smaller cities and towns of New York. Home to a 2016 NIMHD S21 Health Disparities Endowment Grant, a 2009 NIMHD P20 Exploratory Center of Excellence, and a 2004 NIMHD R24 EXPORT Center, CEMHD works toward eliminating health disparities by developing capacity in faculty at the University at Albany and partnering with community groups to identify their health concerns and the sources of disparities, and then plans, implements and tests strategies to alleviate them. CEMHD is a partnership among community groups, hospitals, state and county health departments, the State of New York and the University at Albany. CEMHD's focus on minorities and under-served populations in the smaller cities and towns of Upstate New York is premised upon the notion that health disparities found in these areas differ from those in the larger cities, and that the appropriate solutions will also differ. Since most of the research on minority health disparities, and the programs that have resulted from it, has focused on populations in large cities, relatively little is known about the distinct causes of poorer health among minorities in smaller cities. Therefore, another reason for our geographical emphasis is to fill in a gap in the research and to initiate and test the appropriate solutions.

FY 22-23.mission: Through fundamental and applied interdisciplinary research, the mission of the Atmospheric Sciences Research Center is to expand our understanding of the physical and chemical processes that govern the atmosphere-land-water system to improve the quality of life and economic well-being of citizens across New York State, the nation and the world.
FY 22-23.vision: ​​To maintain and expand ASRC as a global leader in atmospheric and environmental sciences research and its application to the betterment of society, in an inclusive and collaborative environment that values integrity, diversity and the well-being of all.
FY 22-23.topAchievements1: ​ ​Center of Excellence promotes Renewable Energy and Grid Resiliency and is awarded $1M for FY 22/23. The ASRC-led Center of Excellence in Weather and Climate Analytics continues to drive applied research in collaboration with industry. A major activity this past year has been the successful mobilization of support from NSF for an IUCRC planning grant to establish a consortium of industrial partners concerned with Renewable Energy and Grid Resiliency (Weather Innovation and Smart Energy and Resilience WISER). This represents a significant and strategic collaboration with the University of Connecticut. Also, in April we learned the good news that our COE was to be funded at the $1M level for 22/23. Significantly, this included $800K in the executive budget which provides some security for future years. See https//www.albany.edu/news-center/news/2022-plans-new-weather-innovation-smart-energy-and-resilience-center-draw-energy
FY 22-23.topAchievements2: ​ ​Center receives $1M endowment to support research in renewable energy and grid resiliency. During this period ASRC received a $1M endowment to support research in Renewable Energy and Grid Resiliency. The fellowship will provide support for a doctoral fellow focused on interdisciplinary research aimed at enabling effective deployment of renewable energy on the electric grid using innovative insights from the atmospheric sciences and other fields. Research will focus on topics such as advanced resource assessment in a changing climate; large-scale integration of renewable energy on the grid; economic assessment of renewable energy deployments; renewable energy public policy and education; and energy infrastructure resiliency maximization.
FY 22-23.topAchievements3: ​ ​ASRC-led research to help reduce methane emissions in New York. Dr. Jim Schwab is leading a new collaborative project to locate New York’s largest sources of methane emissions using ASRC’s mobile laboratory equipment to collect advanced air quality observations across the state. ASRC received $548,000 from the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority (NYSERDA) through its Environmental Research Program to support this effort. See https//www.albany.edu/news-center/news/2022-asrc-air-quality-researcher-leads-project-help-reduce-methane-emissions-new
FY 22-23.topAchievements4: ​ ​Collaboration with IBM Research. A formal research partnership was announced between UAlbany and IBM Research to work on weather and climate impacts in NY State. Focus areas include harmful algal blooms, winter road weather, flooding, renewable energy and Numerical Weather Prediction. See https//www.albany.edu/news-center/news/2022-ualbany-ibm-announce-new-partnership-research-weather-and-climate-impacts
FY 22-23.topAchievements5: ​ ​Federal Advocacy Success. Through working with our Federal Advocacy firm Clark Hill, we have achieved some notable successes for FY2022. FY2022 (i) $900K of new money was achieved for the Profiler Test Bed Project, in the form of an earmark. (ii) $3M in support of empowering emergency managers with tools derived from mesonet data was included in the form of appropriations language (target DHS S&T). ASRC is working with CEHC to mobilize the $3M. This represents a significant return on investment. Clark Hill continues to advocate for Mesonet-related projects for FY2023 including promotion of research and infrastructure for renewable energy efforts including offshore wind.

FY 23-24.mission: ​​Through fundamental and applied interdisciplinary research, the mission of the Atmospheric Sciences Research Center is to expand our understanding of the physical and chemical processes that govern the atmosphere-land-water system to improve the quality of life and economic well-being of citizens across New York State, the nation and the world.
FY 23-24.vision: ​​To maintain and expand ASRC as a global leader in atmospheric and environmental sciences research and its application to the betterment of society, in an inclusive and collaborative environment that values integrity, diversity and the well-being of all.
FY 23-24.annualBudget: ​​People: ASRC’s 14 faculty and 7 staff (including one full-time staff person at Whiteface Mountain) are supported by UAlbany. Over the past five years, ASRC’s payroll expenditures totaled $10,706,372 – an average of $2,141,274 per year. One full-time research facilitator and one part-time IT support person are supported by the VPR. Post-docs, research scientists, visiting scholars, graduate students, and undergraduate students are primarily paid from research grants; some are supported from start-up funds provided to SUNY2020 faculty. Most ASRC faculty are on 9-month academic year appointments and are paid summer salary from research grants or start-up funds. OTPS: ASRC’s operations, including operations at the UAlbany location and at Whiteface Mountain, are covered by IFR revenue recovered from sponsored programs. Over the past five years, ASRC’s OTPS expenditures at the Albany location have totaled $202,696, an average of $40,539 per year. Not counting annual telephone charges of almost $19,000 per year, OTPS expenses at ASRC average about $21,539 per year. The Whiteface location’s OTPS expenditures over five years total $77,606, an average of $15,521 per year. One faculty member had a legacy IFR account that covered some OTPS expenses such as Verizon Wireless. Strategic Investment: In the past, ASRC has received overhead recovery from the VPR to be used to grow research activity at ASRC. We have about $70,900 remaining in cash to spend on the state-side. On the RF side there is a legacy overhead recovery account primarily used in support of our RF p-card program as the initial source to pay the Bank of America bill monthly; expenses are then moved to the appropriate sponsored award through a reconciliation process. Events: ASRC has both UAlbany Foundation funds in the Ray Falconer Endowment and UAS (Auxiliary Services) funds to support lectures and colloquies.
